div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: TOGO'S VICTORY
div.p: The issue of the battle in the Korean Straits will be far more decisive in its results than the great victory of the Japanese at Mukden or the fall of Port Arthur. Last week's fight will take a foremost rank among the decisive battles of the world's history. In spite of the continuous ill-success that has hitherto attended Russia on land, it must be borne in mind that if Admiral Rodjestvensky had succeeded in wresting from Japan the mastery at sea, the misfortunes already suffered on land would have been in great measure retrieved. If Marshal Oyama’s sea communications were permanently cut, he would be unable to keep his army in condition, and one or two campaigns might brings its ruin. But the victory of Admiral Togo has annihilated the Russian Armada and the greatest naval victory since Trafalgar has been won. The telegrams fail to make clear the strategy of the battle, and we must wait for some time to come before we can judge the actual conditions of the fight. In our leading article yesterday we reviewed the material conditions in the two sides which appeared to balance each other. But it must be remembered that the moral conditions were indisputably in favor of the Japanese. To begin with, they had a practically uninterrupted series of victories to look back upon. Some of their operations failed it is true, but the failure was less due to their enemy than to the difficulty inherent in the operations, if not to their virtual impracticability. The Japanese have displayed every quality which makes for success in maritime war. All Admiral Togo’s officers and men are now veterans to warfare. All have “seen blood about the decks,” and are habituated to the habit of mind desirable when an enemy is at hand. It is quite different with their opponents, of whom nearly all made acquaintance with the realities of war for the first time when they got near the Japanese fleet on Saturday week. Another point in Japan’s favor was that when Admiral Togo’s fleet was called on to fight he went into action with an advantage on his side which has hitherto been denied him. In all previous engagements he has been obliged to make allowance for the arrival of a Russian fleet from Europe. Consequently, he was never able to push his attacks home. He had to husband his fleet, the only one that his country possessed, so as to be able to meet the force expected from Europe when the latter arrived in the theatre of war. This he was not obliged to do when he fell upon the Russian Armada in the Korean Straits on Saturday, no longer impeded by what hitherto has been a serious obstacle.

As to the behaviour of the Russians and the handling of their fleet no details are yet available, but the Russian naval record is not very inspiring, and in this connection we may recall the behaviour of the Russian Fleet when it made its great sortie from Port Arthur under Admiral Prince Outomsky. On that occasion, although the strength of the Russian Fleet was such that, if properly handled, it stood every chance of disputing the command of the sea on equal grounds with Japan, it, nevertheless, abandoned all idea of a fight to a finish, and instead, acted like a flock of helpless sheep before a pack of wolves. Only one ship in the whole of that great squadron distinguished itself at any time, and that was the cruiser “Rayan,” whose captain, alone among them all, had fought his ship throughout in a gallant and seamanlike manner. The inaction of the Russian destroyers during all the weary months of blockade was as contemptible as it was surprising, and for the credit of their commanding officers, we can only suppose that either they were suffering from a shortage of supplies in torpedoes, or that, as has been reported in well-informed quarters, the stock of “war-heads” for them was almost nil--in which case the destroyers would be useless except for use as scouts or dispatch boats. Otherwise, it is difficult to understand why, during the months of blockade not a single torpedo attack was delivered against Togo’s naval base at the Elliott Islands.

It is not likely that Rodjestvensky’s officers were capable of showing more dash and initiative than their fellows have done in the past, for whatever may be said in praise of defensive ability shown by General Kuropatkin and of the indomitable staying power of his troops, the Russian record at sea has hitherto been one of almost unredeemed discredit. The ponderous inertia which incapacitates the Muscovite temperament for the great aggressive, but makes it incalculably formidable for resistance upon land, can exercise no such negative power at sea. The fleet that cannot develop superior offensive ability must be lost, and the Slav has yet to prove his possession of the rudiments of naval aptitude. The Baltic provinces, no doubt, furnish a proportion of fine officers and fine men, but that they are enough to leaven the lump for any hopeful purpose nothing has hitherto suggested. This was not always the view of Europe. In the eighteenth century speculative politicians in many countries that that Russia might conceivably become the first naval Power in the world. That was the opinion of the Abbé Raynal, in his “Histoire Philosophique des Deux Indes”--that eloquent and penetrating oration in ten volumes which coloured the whole of Napoleon's early views about politics at large and sea-power in particular. It was thought that as trade followed the flag, fleets would follow the timber. The Baltic, in the days of wooden navies, was the great store-house of naval materials. The fear of being cut off from that source of supply had always been a serious anxiety to England, Holland, and France, possessing no adequate forests of their own. This was the chief reason for the preference given to the import of American timber under our old Colonial system, which sprang out of facts, not theories. Russia, possessing the material, as the Abbé Raynal imagined, would create the equivalent navy. The logic was as if you could make any man an incomparable virtuoso by presenting him with Paganini’s violin. Nothing ever was more superficial than the view commonly held a few years ago, that the equal development of destructive machinery upon modern warships would neutralise the superior aptitude of born naval races. The relative value of a machine depends upon the man who works it. The habits of coolness, rapidity, and certainty in action are at least as decisive in our time as in that of Nelson. Russia can spend vast sums upon purchasing and equipping warships, but it takes more than the money and more than the vessels to make a fleet. Sea-power has always belonged to the free. Liberty develops the qualities that win and keep it. Despotism depresses them, and Russia has yet to develop the qualities that would be required to make her a great naval nation.

div.head: TOGO’S VICTORY. CAPTURE OF NEBOGATOFF. PURSUIT CONTINUED. LIST OF SHIPS SUNK OR CAPTURED TOGO’S FLEET UNDAMAGED
div.p: Tokio, May 29.
Admiral Nebogatoff has been captured, with 3,000 bluejackets. Admiral Rodjestvensky appears to have escaped.
The battle began on Saturday. The pursuit continues.

Admiral Togo states that he has sunk the following ships . — “Borodino,” “Imperator Alexandre,” ‘ Admiral Nakhimoff,” “Dimitri Donskoi,” “Vladimir Monomakh," “Admiral Oushakoff," “Svietlana,” “Jemchug,” “Kamchatka," and “Irtessim.”
He has captured the “Orel," “Imperator Nikolai I.," “Admiral Seniavin,” “General Adm. Apraxine," and “Admiral Sissoi Veliky.’’
The Japanese Fleet sustained no damage.
(Havas.)
Tokio, May 29.

The battleships “Borodino, “Ushakoff," and “Alexander III.,” the cruisers “Nakhimoff,'' “Dimitri Donskoi," “Vladimir Monomakh," “Svietlana," “Jemchug, “Kamchatka", and "Irtessim have been sunk. The battleships “Orel," “Nicholai I.," “Admiral Seniavin, " and “Admiral Apraxine," have been captured.
Admiral Niebogatoff and 3,000 officers and men have been captured. Admiral Rodjestvensky appears to have escaped. The pursuit continues.
Admiral Togo reports that three more destroyers have been sunk and one transport and one destroyer captured. The fighting lasted Saturday and Sunday. The Japanese fleet is undamaged. (Reuter.)
Washington, May 29.
The Admiralty learns that the battleship Sisoi Veliki has been captured, and the flag-ship “Knyaz Suvaroff" seriously damaged, (R.)

div.head: RECEPTION OF NEWS IN LONDON.
div.p: London, May 29.

There has been a sharp advance in Japanese securities. All markets are stronger. The news of the victory is received with general satisfaction here and is regarded as improving the prospect of peace. (Reuter. )

div.head: BARON HAYASHI INTERVIEWED.
div.p: London, May 29.

Baron Hayashi, in an interview with Reuter’s representative, said that he rejoices that Admiral Togo’s victory is in the centenary year of the battle of Trafalgar. The Japanese have not been without anxiety ; but their minds are easy now with regard to further operations. ( Reuter.)

div.head: MR BALFOUR INDISPOSED VOTE OF CENSURE POSTPONED.
div.p: London, May 29.
Mr. Balfour is laid up with a severe chill. The vote of censure has been postponed. (R.)

div.head: CRETAN DISTURBANCES. DESPATCH OF BRITISH TROOPS.
div.p: Malta, May 29.
540 of the 2nd Sussex Regiment have left for Crete, which continues to be much disturbed. (Reuter.)

div.head: ATLANTIC YACHT RACE. WON BY AMERICAN BOAT.
div.p: Plymouth, May 29.
The American yacht ''Atlantic'’ has been signalled off the Lizard, thus winning the Emperor William s Cup for the Atlantic race. (Reuter.)

div.head: CRICKET
div.p: London, May 29.
England beat Australia by 196 runs. Tyldesley 56. Australia made 158 for 4 wickets, when the innings was declared closed. Noble 50, Hill 54. (Reuter).

[We give this telegram as received, but the more probable reading should, we think, be that England made 196 runs in their first innings, and that Australia had scored 158 for 4 wickets, when the stumps were drawn at the end of the first day’s play. ---Ep. E.G.

div.head: Epidemic.
div.p: —Relapsing fever has broken out in the Kafr Zayat district.

div.head: The Austro-Hungarian Diplomatic Agency
div.p: will be transferred to Alexandria about the middle of June.

div.head: German Mission.
div.p: —The remaining portion of the German Mission to Abyssinia has arrived at Port Said and embarked for Berlin.

div.head: The Ministers.
div.p: —The Regent and the Ministers will remain in Cairo until June 12, when they will proceed to Alexandria for the summer.
Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Boulac district of Cairo during the night of Thursday and at daylight on Friday, will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: Horse Show.
div.p: —Persons attending the Horse Show at the Trotter Egyptien on Saturday next may have lunch on the grounds by ordering tables not later than Thursday.

div.head: Quarantine in Turkey.
div.p: — A telegram from Constantinople states that arrivals from Fort Said arc subjected to a medical examination and disinfection, while rats on board are destroyed.

div.head: English Church Services.
div.p: —Since the June list of the Mansourah and Tantah services was published it has been thought advisable to alter the hour of the morning service from 11 a.m. to 9.30 a.m. until further notice.

div.head: Dramatic Performance.
div.p: — The Ernesto Rossi dramatic club are giving a mixed programme to-morrow evening at the Popular Conservatoire of Music, no theatre being available. The performance will begin at 9.15 p.m.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: —12 vessels passed through the Canal on the 26th inst., 8 of which were British, 1 Austrian, 1 German, 2 Italian. The day’s receipts were frs. 299,075.71, making the total amount received from 1st inst. frs. 8,015,643.61.

div.head: The Cotton Worm.
div.p: —The Ministry of the Interior has sent to each of the members or the Legislative Council a copy of the circular giving a description of the cotton worm which has made its appearance at Kafr Khadr, Gharbieh province.

div.head: Khedivial School of Law.
div.p: —Yacoub Pasha Artin, Under Secretary of State for the Ministry of Public Instruction, has informed Omar Bey Loutfy that in consequence of the decision of the medical commission on the 23rd inst. his resignation has been accepted.

div.head: Official Salaries.
div.p: — The report on the salaries of officials in the service of the Egyptian Government, which Mr. Machell has recently drawn up, is now in the hands of the Financial Adviser. It is not as yet decided whether it will be given in full to the Press.

div.head: An Outbreak of Fire
div.p: occurred in a house in the native quarter of Cairo at Darb el-Hamr, on Sunday morning. The Fire Brigade, under the command of Captain Blake, promptly arrived on the scene and the fire was quickly extinguished, though not before three rooms had been destroyed.

div.head: Hotel Beau-Rivage.
div.p: —On the occasion of the first ball of the season at the hotel, by kind permission of the Colonel and officers, the band of the Royal Berkshire Regiment will perform during dinner and for the dance. Tables for dinner on that evening should be retained by Wednesday night.

div.head: Murder by Ghaffir.
div.p: —Two days ago a native of Itlidim attempted to enter the precincts of the market there to sell his cattle, when he was stopped by a ghaffir, who told him that all such business was prohibited owing to the cattle plague. A row ensued, and the ghaffir ended the discussion by killing the fellah with his nabout.

div.head: Death from Alcoholic Poisoning.
div.p: — A Sudanese was found by the police yesterday in Bab el Bahr street in a very advanced state of intoxication, and as he had entirely lost the power of speech be was taken to hospital, where he soon afterwards expired. The post-mortem examination showed that death was due to alcoholic poisoning.

div.head: Army of OCCUPATION.
div.p: —Colonel J. Magill, M.D.,C.B., R.A.M C., P.M.O. in Egypt, accompanied by Major F. W. Hardy, R.A.M.C., Sanitary Officer in Egypt, will go to Candia, Crete, on the 14th June, to make the annual inspection of barracks and hospitals in that station. During the absence of Colonel J. Magill, the duties of officiating Principal Medical Officer will be performed by Lieut. Col O. Todd, R.A.M.C.

div.head: Water Main Bursts.
div.p: —On Sunday after noon the water main leading from the Station square, Cairo,to the Esbekieh burst and flooded the square and adjoining streets. The Water Company immediately stopped their pumps working in order to reduce the pressure, and sent workmen to repair the main, a task which lasted well into the night A large number of men were also sent to clear the streets from the flood of water, which made them almost impassale, and very quickly effected a great improvement in their condition.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA. HARBOUR. NEW PASS TO BE MADE. IMPORTANT UNDERTAKING.
div.p: A most important improvement in the port of Alexandria is to be undertaken immediately, and to morrow the first dredger for the work is arriving at Alexandria. The Egyptian Government has determined to construct anewpassfor entrance to the harbour as owing to the enormous and continuous increase in the size of modern vessels the present entry by way of the Boghaz pass is too small for the largest type of ships. For instance, when the White Star liner “Celtic” arrived here the season before last she had to lie outside the harbour.

The Boghsz pass is only 31 feet in depth and can only admit as a maximum vessels drawing from 29 to 30 feet of water, and then only in the smoothest sea. The Dew pass is to bo dredged to the depth of 35 feet and will thus be able to admit the largest ships alloat

The dredger, which arrives from Malta tomorrow, is convoyed by H. M. S. “Juno," a second-class cruiser under the command or Captain Christian, R.N. This dredger, the “St. Lawrence,” belongs to the Admiralty and is of the type known as “Saints.” She has very powerful machinery and it is expected that her dredging capacity is approximately six hundred tons per hour.

The construction of the new pass will begin at once. It will make the harbour most efficient for the alternative entrance will be especially useful when one orotherof the passes gets blocked. The new pass will be the same as the present pass from a navigator’s point of view, with leading lights.
The Ports and Lighthouses Administration is also negotiating with the Admiralty for the hire of a second dredger for the same work. Another dredger is arriving from Cyprus in about ten days’ time.

div.head: FRUIT AND VEGETABLE DISEASES.
div.p: Mr. Balls, the botanist of the Khedivial Agricultural Society, has been paying a visit to Alexandria in order to examine the cause of the strawberry disease in the gardens of the Mahmoudieh Canal. He found a worm, which he took to Cairo to be examined by the entomologist, Mr. Willcocks. He also collected worms that attack the sweet potato crop, and several specimens of diseased apricots, French beans, tomatoes, roses, etc.

div.head: LAND AND MORTGAGE OF EGYPT.
div.p: The report of the annual general meeting of the Land and Mortgage Company of Egypt should afford considerable encouragement to the various land and trust companies which have been lately started in Egypt, for if this company can find such scope for useful and extensive operations, there is no reason why the new ventures should not have equally pleasant prospects. That the making of loans on first mortgage can be made remunerative is evidenced by the satisfactory story which the chair-man, Sir E. L. Pemberton, had to tell at the meeting in London on Saturday week. The dividend of 10 per cent. is the highest ever declared by the company. The chairman explained that although in consequence of increasing competition the rate of interest had been reduced, the loans were so well placed that no falling off in the business need be anticipated. Looking at the above results, it is evident that the company’s prosperity is increasing with that of the country generally.

div.head: THE PIGMIES
div.p: Colonel Harrison, who has been ill since his return home, has been engaged in making all arrangements before the pigmies’ arrival in England. The directors of the London Hippodrome have engaged them to appear at the London Hippodrome immediately after their arrival at the Royal Albert Docks, probably on June 5.

There is a sort of disposition still prevalent to regard these little people as filling, more or less, the part of the “missing link,” but low though they stand in the comparative social scale, they seem to present no marked features whatever to warrant their being placed outside the class of various other ill-developed peoples. Even the silence and apathy of which so much has been made are fully paralleled among the Indian forest races of South America. They are directly attributable to the oppressive gloom and monotony of the surroundings in which for generations they have passed their

It is not generally known that several of these little people have been educated and baptised in connection with the C.M.S. Mission in the Uganda Protectorate. One of them is a teacher in a mission school in Toro, near the Ruwenzori Mountains. Writing of the school to children in England, a lady missionary says : "Listen to this ; one class that is being taught by a pigmy from Stanley’s Great Forest, who recently was baptised. His name is Bulasio, and be is very fond of dealing out whacks with that little cane, whenever a pupil slackens in his reading, or does not show him due respect.”

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: 2s. PER DAY. WINE INCLUDED.
xxxxx-1x.7

div.head: ARISTON AERATED WATERS
div.p: Guaranteed Distilled.
ALEXANDRIA: 7 Rue de la Poste.
CAIRO opposite the Tramways Co. Works, Sharia Sahal, Kasr-el-Nil

div.head: ANGLO-AMERICAN NILE. YEAR OP EXCEPTIONAL PROSPERITY.
div.p: The following is the report of the board of directors of the Anglo-American Nile Steamers & Hotel Co., Ltd., read at the general meeting of share holders held in Cairo to-day :—

The directors, in presenting their fifth annual report and balance sheet, are able to congratulate the shareholders on a year or exceptional prosperity in the history of the company, and to point to a steady increase in all branches of their business, the profits from all sources rising from LE. 18,086 in 1903 to L.E. 19,471 in 1904, and LE. 24,197 in 1905. These results have been achieved in the face of very severe competition in the freight service dating from the reduction of the Railway Administration’s tariff, which involved a corresponding decrease in the rates charged by the company. The increase of river and canal traffic between Cairo and Alexandria had led to the issue of certain Government regulations which, if adhered to, are likely to have serious results upon the future of transport by steam barge in this country, Representations are, however, being made to the Public Works Department which it is hoped will lead to their modification

div.head: MENZALEH CANAL & NAVIGATION Co.
div.p: Allusion was made in the last report to an arrangement by virtue of which an option on the unissued share capital of the company was given against £10,000 of debentures in the company taken firm by a local group and the New Egyptian Company. The results of this operation have been fully commensurate with the directors’ expectations. A valuable holding has been secured in the Menzaleh Canal and Navigation Company shares; the order for the construction of their fleet is being carried out in the company’s workshops ; and the central management thereof is assured to this company for a period of two years at a remuneration of £500 per annum.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL, ASSOUAN.
div.p: Apart from profits derived from the usual sources of business, a special profit has been made on the sale of the Savoy Hotel at Assouan, which has been transferred for a sum of £60,000 to the newly-formed Upper Egypt Hotels Co. The sale was made for cash, and the second instalment of £30,000 has been paid over since the accounts have been closed. The directors are of opinion that this profit should be considered as extraordinary and dealt with accordingly. They therefore propose that ten thousand pounds shall be placed to reserve and that the whole of the preliminary expenses, amounting to L.E. 2,983.202 m/m, be written off. The continued existence of this account, which has no realisable value, appears to them undesirable. The directors, although entitled by law and precedent to their percentage of this profit, are strongly of opinion that in cases where a profit is dealt with as extraordinary and not distributed by way of dividend, the Board should also forego their claim to a share in it. No deduction on this account has therefore been made.

div.head: REDEMPTION OF DEBENTURES
div.p: The sale of the Savoy Hotel had allowed of the amortisation of the debenture debt of the company amounting to £35,000. The interest on these debentures at the rate of six per cent. constituted a heavy charge for the company, and the directors are confident, that should occasion to borrow arise in the future, they will be able to do so on more advantageous terms. As amortisation only commenced as from May 1, no change is shown in the balance-sheet in the total amount of debentures outstanding on 30th April, 1904.

div.head: RESERVE FUND
div.p: Out of a total issue of £35,000, £1.500 had already been redeemed ; this amount, being in the nature of a reserve, will now be definitely transferred to that fund which, with the propos ed addition of L.E. 10,000 and the existing sum of L.E. 541.164 m/m, will then amount to over L.E. 12,000. The directors have decided that the reserve fund shall be invested outside the ordinary business of the company.

div.head: EMPLOYMENT OF CAPITAL
div.p: A portion of the company’s capital remain ing at the present time unengaged, the means by which it can be profitably employed are having the careful consideration of the board.

div.head: Mr. THUBRON’S RETIREMENT.
div.p: Mr. E. B. Thubron having informed the board that his numerous engagements did not admit of his devoting as much time to the business of the company as seemed to him desirable, an arrangement was concluded, dating from September 1, 1904, by which Mr. Thubron, while retaining certain benefits of contract, retiree from the service of the com nany as managing director.

div.head: DIVIDEND.
div.p: The directors propose to pay a dividend of 8% , and a bonus of 1 % and to carry forward a balance of L.E. 2,748.357 m/m. After making provision for depreciation and maintenance, interest on debentures and on the bank over draft, and the writing off of the whole of the preliminary expenses, there remains to be distributed on this season's working alone, a sum of…..L.E. 20,207 457 from which the directors pro pose to pay a dividend 5% …. „ 4,956,250 Leaving a balance of….L.E. 15,251,207 To reserve account …. 10,000,000 10 % to board ….L.E. 5,251,207 525,120 Brought forward from last year…..L.E. 4,726 087 1, 987,270 L.E. 6,713,357 L.E. Supplementary dividend 3%.. 2,973,750 Bonus of 1% 991,250 “ 3,965,000 Carried forward to profit and loss account next year… L.E. 2,748,357

The directors have to announce with great regret the retirement of Mr. F.T. Rowlett from the board owing to pressure of work. Mr. Astley Friend, manager of the Cairo Water Works, has been elected to a seat on the board, and the general meeting will be asked to confirm his nomination.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
DEPARTURE OP JAPANESE AGENT
div.p: Mr. Tanaka, the Japanese Agent who has been in Port Said since December last, leaves for the East to-day on board the North German Lloyd S.S. “Sachsen.”

div.head: FIRE AT THE STATION.
div.p: Port-Said, Sunday.

Last night, one or two waggons filled with general merchandise, among which was a large quantity of petroleum, caught fire at the railway station. In a very short time a spare locomotive was brought along and the burning waggons were pulled away up a siding, where they were allowed to burn themselves out. No damage was done to the station itself.

div.head: CHERCHEZ LA FEMME.
div.p: About 10.30 p.m. yesterday the police were summoned to what is commonly known as the rue Babel, in a particularly disorderly house of which, called the Hotel d'Athènes, a fight was in progress, terminating in a Greek firing with a revolver at another, and severely wounding him in the head. The cause of the discussion is somewhat shrouded in mystery, but there is no doubt that it is a case “cherchez la femme,” having due regard to the locality. The man was arrested and conveyed to the caracol, and his victim taken in, an ambulance to the hospital, where, on enquiry, I learn he is progressing favorably.

div.head: GYMKHANA.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon, close to the tennis ground, there was held a Gymkhana, which, though in itself successful, was very sparsely attended owing to the fact of its taking place being so little known. It is said that several will be held this summer, at regular intervals.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ.
RUSSIAN HOSPITAL SHIP.
div.p: The British India steamer “Jelunga,” from Shanghai, chartered by the Russian Government as a hospital ship, arrived at Suez at 5 o'clock this morning, and entered the CaEal at 11 a.m. bound to Sebastopol. The “Jelunga” had on board 1,019 naval officers and men from the destroyed battleships and cruisers in Port Arthur, all of whom took an active put in the defence of the fortresses and were subsequently taken prisoners and released on '‘parole.” Several of the men were in a pitiful state, having their legs, arms, and eyes missing. Amongst the prisoners there were eight ladies who had acted as nurses at Port Arthur during the siege.

div.head: COAL FOR RODJESTVENSKY.
div.p: The Hamburg-Amerika liners “Batavia” and “Badenia,’ chartered by the Russian Government, returned to Sues and entered the Canal last Saturday evening and this day respectively, in ballast, after having delivered their cargo of coal to Admiral Rodjestvensky 's squadron near Madagascar.

div.head: FRENCH MISSION STARTING.
div.p: To-morrow morning a French mission, con sisting of one naval and one military officer and five other Frenchmen, accompanied by a Syrian doctor and escorted by about 60 Bedouins, with about 40 camels laden with water and pro visions, will start from Moses’ Wells en route to Muscat, in the Persian Gulf The mission will travel the whole way by camel, and its objects are said to be scientific and geographical.

div.head: CAIRO WATER SUPPLY.
div.p: It will be interesting to Cairo residents to learn that in a fortnight’s time all possibility of shortage of water supply will be removed as by that time the Water Company will have start ed pumping water from the artesian wells at Rod-el Farag, which will enable them to pump an extra 25,000 cubic metres of water per day, should the necessity arise. This method of water supply will be continued for two years, when, if it is found satisfactory, the system will be entirely adopted, and the present system done away with. But in the meantime should the amount pumped from the artesian wells prove insufficient they will be able to pump from the plant at present in use, end thus prevent any shortage.

Regarding the insufficient supply, of which we have of late received complaints, we learn that the maximum amount which the company is compelled to pump per day, according to the contract with the Government, is 30,000 cubic metres, whereas they have pumped as much as 75,000 cubic metres in one day. It is also interesting to note that they have pumped 68,101, 940 litres of water so far this year, whilst during the corresponding period last year they only pumped 44, 835, 880 litres, thus making an increase of 23, 266, 060 litres.

We have mentioned before that the price of ice as supplied by the company is P.T. 3-5 per block. The company informs us that they sell the whole of the ice produced to Messrs. Boehms and Anderer, who are under control not to sell at any higher rate than P.T.3-5, whatever the consumption may be, and it is only on account of people buying ice from other persons than the recognised agents that a higher rate is paid.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: It is stated that the Sultan intends to confer the rank of Moushif on the Regent and the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

The native Press is speculating a good deal on the reasons which led to the selection of Boutros Pasha Ghali to accompany the Khedive to Europe. It is said that he went to Constantinople in order to settle the question of the Coptic Convent at Jerusalem. Another theory is that he is to be Prime Minister on the retirement of Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, and so he has gone to England to make himself acquainted with the King.

The Earl of Galloway, who is to be chairman of the new North Egypt Land Company, is the eleventh holder of the title, and is concerned in no small amount of land nearer home, the death of his brother four years ago having made him not only an Earl but the owner of eighty thousand acres. Lord Galloway was known until that event occurred as Captain Randolph Stewart, of the Black Watch, a veteran of Crimea and of the Mutiny, and in October next he will be entering upon his seventieth year. Descended from the Stewarts of whom the Kings of Scotland and of England were a branch, Lord Galloway owes his title to that Sir Alexander Stewart who, in 1607, was created Lord of Garlies, and advanced to an earldom by James the Sixth in 1623.

H.E. Mokham el Dawla Mirza Mahmoud Khan arrived at Alexandria yesterday evening from Cairo. His Excellency is leaving for Europe in order to be in attendance on the Shah of Persia during his Majesty’s visit to Europe.
H.H. the Khedive has conferred the grade of Mirmiran (pasha) on Amin Pasha and Ghamzi, notables of Zagazig.
Lieut.-Gen. F. G. Slade is on promotion to retain his appointment as Inspector-General of Royal Garrison Artillery.
Sir Wm. Willcocks’ journey to Constantinople is said to be connected with his project for the irrigation of Mesopotamia.
Dr. Ruffer, Director of the Quarantine Service, will leave for England on the 15th of next month.
Contrary to former announcements, Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria, will leave for Europe on June 17, and will be absent from Egypt for, 3 ½ months.
El Miralai Matchett Bey, Commanding Cairo District, and El Bimbashi Clayton, Deputy Assistant Adjutant General, who have been in Alexandria on duty, returned to Cairo on Sunday.
Three months’ leave has been accorded to Saghcolaghasi V. Jarvis, Inspector of Police, Cairo from June 22.

The following visitors are staying at the Beau Rivage Hotel, Ramleh: Mr. and Mrs. G. D. Hornblower, Judge and Mrs. J.E. Marshall, the Misses Marshall, Mrs. J. H. Farrar and courier, the Misses Farrar, Mr and Mrs. G. Heins and family, Mr. and Mrs. A. Miller and family, Mr. W. S. Balls, Mr. F.S. Walton, Mr. Temple, Mr. Edgeworth, Miss Lewis Stewart, Miss L. Wahrmer, Dr. and Mrs. Amb. G. Ralli, Capt. and Mrs. W. H. Rotheram, Mr. and Mrs. B. Bernandos, Miss A. Ardener, Miss H. Cay, Miss E. Mason.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit---within certain necessary limits--free discussion.

div.head: A.S.C. AND PIGEON SHOOTING.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,-- I was delighted to see the noble protest of your correspondent in to-day’s “Gazette” against the scheme of having pigeon shooting at the Alexandria Sporting Club. The latest London papers announce that this wicked and cruel so-called “sport” has been expelled from Hurlingham. Every genuine sportsman will rejoice at the decision of the Hurlingham Club to erase pigeon shooting from the list of “sports” practised at the club. It would be difficult to advance a single argument in favor of its continuance, save that of ancient usage, from which standpoint is claims are equalled, if not surpassed, by those of cock-fighting or bear-baiting. Even in its least objectionable form, pigeon-shooting falls far below the modern standard of sport, in the lack of a fair chance of escape for the quarry. In its lower, hole-and-corner aspects, it lends itself to abominable cruelties, inflicted upon the birds in order to affect their flight when they rise from the trap. The value of Hurlingham’s decision lies not only in its immediate effect, but in the promise which it holds out that either by force of example or by actual legislation the “sport” may be abolished altogether throughout England, and a blot which disfigures our sporting annals be thus for ever removed. Let the A.S.C. take note, I am, Sir,

div.head: CAIRO BRITISH CHARITABLE SOCIETY
REPORT FOR THE YEAR 1904
div.p: At the beginning of the year there was a cash balance of P.T. 1,849. The total receipts during the year amounted to P.T. 40,676. The subscriptions and * donations amounted to P.T. 37,596 as compared with P.T. 15,216 on the occasion when the last previous collection was made. The expenditure in 1904 amounted to P.T. 23,746, as compared with P.T. 19,864 in 1903.

There was a decrease in expenditure under the following heads :--1. Loans granted ; 2. relief at Rudolph’s Home and school fees ; 3. fares to Alexandria, etc. ; 4. burial and funeral expenses. There was an increase in the amounts expended on passages to England, etc., and on hospital and medicines. As regards the first item, the most costly case was that of a mining engineer, who, though of English birth, had his home and family in Australia and had therefore to be sent there. His relief and re-patriation cost the fund P.T. 2,599. The next most important case was that of a governess whose passage to England cost the fund £10. With regard to hospital fees it should be stated that out of the total of P.T. 7,581 more than P.T. 2,500 was expended on the maintenance at the Asylum of pauper lunatics. There was a cash balance at the end of 1904 of P.T. 18,779. The total assets at the end of 1904 amounted to P.T. 29,309 as compared with P.T. 12,925 at the end of 1903. The total number of cases dealt with by the fund was 122 as compared with 128 in the previous year. ** There was an increase of 10 in the number of natives of the United Kingdom who were relieved. Besides the relief given out of the fund, the Government of Malta expended on hospital treatment and burials of distressed Maltese a total sum of £188.0.3.
*Among the donations was one of £50 from the Daira Saideh Administration and one of £50 from Mr. Pissoi, a Greek subject.
** Of these 51 were natives of the United Kingdom, 54 Maltese, 10 British Indians, and 7 Colonial subjects.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS
div.p: The King has been pleased to give and grant unto Major and Brevet Lieutenant-Colonel Lord Edward Herbert Cecil, D.S.O., Grenadier Guards, his Majesty’s Royal licence and authority that he may accept and wear the Insignia of the Second Class of the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Medjidieh, conferred upon him by his Highness the Khedive of Egypt, authorised by his Imperial Majesty the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered to his Highness.

The King has been pleased to give and grant unto Maurice Moberly, Esq., Inspector in the Egyptian Ministry of the Interior, his Majesty’s Royal licence and authority that he may accept and wear the Insignia of the Second Class of the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Medjidieh, conferred upon him by his Highness the Khedive of Egypt, authorised by his Imperial Majesty the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered to his Highness. (“London Gazette”).

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
AVIS
div.p: La Municipalite met en adjudication les travaux de construction d'un chalet pour Latrines Publiques sur l'emplacement qui sera destine par la Municipalite sur la Place Mohamed Aly.
Le cautionnement est fixe a L.E. 30 (trente).
Le cahier des charges est depose au Bureau Technique ou il peut etre consulte par les interessea tous les jours de 9 h. a midi, les jours feries exceptes.
Les offres devront etre adressees sous plicachete a Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalite avant le 13 juin 1905.
Elles pourront egalement etre deposees en seance de la Delegation le meme jour a 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : "Soumission pour la construction d'un chalet pour Latrines Publiques."

Le cautionnement ou le recu d'une banque, d'apres les conditions du cahier des charges, devra etre remis separement au Service de la Comptabilite Generale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 13 juin pr. a midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera ecartee.
L'Administrateur
W.P. Chataway.

div.head: LAND AND MORTGAGE CO. OF EGYPT, LIMITED.
IMPROVED POSITION OF THE COMPANY.
DIVIDEND INCREASED.
div.p: The twenty-fifth annual general meeting of the shareholders of the Land and Mortgage Company of Egypt, Limited, was held on the 19th inst., at Cannon-street Hotel, E.C., under the presidency of Sir Edward Leigh Pemberton, K.C.B. (the chairman).
The Secretary (Mr. J. Chisholm) read the notice convening the meeting and the auditors' report.

The Chairman said : On the last two or three occasions I have had the pleasure of addressing you I think I have commenced by address by saying that I hoped the shareholders had as much pleasure in reading the report as the directors had in preparing it. At the risk of appearing monotonous and incapable of any fresh ideas on the subject, I should like to begin in the same way to-day, because I am convinced that the shareholders will have read the report with much satisfaction. We told you last year that we had every reason to be satisfied with the position of the company and that we looked forward with confidence to the future. The result of the past year's working has shown that we were not too sanguine. The reserve fund has been built up to £50,000, in addition to the capital reserve of £25, 180, and that amount having been obtained, we have decided to distribute the bulk of the year's profits in payment of the dividend. We propose to pay at the rate of 10 per cent. for the whole year, as against 9 per cent. for the preceding one. We are glad to be able to do this with still a margin left, as we feel that the shareholders have exercised much patience and forbearance in the past, and are entitled to the full benefit of our present prosperity.

The amount of capital invested this time last year was L.E.459,567. During the past year new loans and investments have been made amounting to L.E. 131,316, making, together, L.E. 680,883. I might here mention that, according to Mr. Hrui's report, all these new investments are on first-rate securities. From this sum of L.E. 680,883 has to be deducted the sum of L.E. 87,235 for payments by the usual working of amortisation--- that is to say, the gradual paying off of loans as previously advanced. The present capital, therefore is L.E. 593,648, thus showing an increase of L.E. 44,081. This is the largest amount invested at any date since the foundation of the company. (Hear, hear.) I called attention last year to the great prosperity of Egypt, and I am happy to say that it continues and extends to every branch of business. We cannot, however, expect for ever to maintain the high rate of interest we have sometimes received, particularly in the face of existing competition and the floation of many new companies doing the same business. We hope to obtain our share in the new business, and I may mention that there is still a demand for money on the part of persons who are investing in the purchase of land. On this point, I should like to read to you an extract or two from our friend Mr. Huri's report as to the position and future value of land in Egypt. He says: "Another factor which has contributed, and will always contribute, to maintain the value of land is the great number of native landowners, large and small, who have no debt and who would absorb any quantity of land which would be offered. Such people, who have excess of revenue over expenditure and who trust no other investment than purchase of land, will always buy land, and they do not consider the present prices as too high. Land to be reclaimed has much increased in value ; for two reasons: first, that the Government has stopped the sale of their waste land, and, secondly, the large margin between the purchase price of this category of land, with cost of reclaiming work, and the present value of good land. Very renumerative business has been done in this branch, which is being taken advantage of by private individuals and by companies. But where the rise has been most marked is in the value of land for building purposes in Cairo and Alexandria and their suburbs. There the increase has attained incredible proportions, and one cannot say that it is not justified. The increase of population and of the welfare of the people, and the penetration of modern ideas as to comfort and sanitation among the natives have proved important factors in enhancing the price of land. New quarters are continually created, with wide streets and magnificent buildings, and rent is steadily increasing. Large fortunes are being made in this branch of business, and companies are being started for this purpose. Up to the present time, with experience and discernment in the choice of the spots, there is still room for good business in these two branches.

I only refer to these extracts to show you that we may not maintain the present high rate of interest. There is still very good business to be done in the future, and of which, I need not say, we are convinced Mr. Huri will secure us our fair proportion. I will now turn to the accounts which you have before you. The gross earnings for the year, you will see, amount to £44, 291 9s. 8d., and after deducting total expenditure, including interest form debentures amounting to £27,202 2s. 3d., the net earnings for the year are £17,089 7s. 5d., to which add balance brought forward from last year's account, £2,400 8s. 2d., making together £19,489 15s. 7d. From this we deduct the interim dividend paid on November 12 last, amounting to £ 6,750, which leaves a balance of £12,789 15s. 7d. Out of this the directors have placed

£2,000 to reserve for contingencies and granted £350 to the staff's provident fund, leaving an available balance of £10,389 15s. 7d. Out of this we recommend a dividend of 5 ½ per cent. for the past six months which, with the 4 ½ per cent. paid in November, will make a dividend of 10 per cent. for the year. This will absorb £8,250, leaving the sum of £2,139 15s. 7d. to be carried forward. In order that you may see that the directors have not acted inadvisedly in making this recommendation without consulting Mr. Huri, who is the gentleman chiefly to be consulted on the subject, I should like to read you another extract from his report, which shows that he approved of what we are going to do. It is as follows: "The board having decided to stop building their reserve and to divide the yearly earnings amongst shareholders, we have to consider what can be fairly reckoned on as an average net profit in the future. Well, considering the very sound and solid position of the company, the perfect safety of our business, and the prosperity of the country, also considering that we shall be able henceforth to have the whole sum of £400,000 at our disposal, and that we have devery reason to hope that no important sum will remain idle on this side, I honestly believe, as far as a man can make prognostications for years to come, that a net profit of £15,000 will not be an exaggerated average; so that I think you can safely inaugurate this year the era of a ten per cent. dividend." If you approve of that, we hope in the future to pay you 10 per cent. by equal half-yearly payments---that is to say, 5 per cent. in November next and 5 per cent. in May. I have referred once or twice to my friend, Mr. Huri, who, I am happy to say, is present to-day and will be able to give you any information you wish. I am sure the shareholders will recognise, as the directors have always done, the great debt of gratitude they owe to Mr. Huri for the ability and devotion he has given to the company's affairs. I will now simply propose : "That the report and accounts of the directors, submitted to this meeting, be, and are hereby received and adopted, and that, as recommended by the board, a dividend at the rate of 10 per cent. per annum on the paid-up share capital of the company for the year ended March 31, 1905-- (consisting of an interim dividend of 4 ½ per cent. for the six months ended September 30, 1904, paid by the board on account in November last, and 5 ½ per cent. for the six months ended March 31 last, now to be paid), be, and is hereby, declared payable, free of income-tax."
Viscount Hampden, G.C.M.G., seconded the motion.

Mr. Skeel said there were two classes of shareholders who certainly ought to congratulate the directors on the satisfactory result they had obtained, namely, the original shareholders, who paid £5 for their shares, and those shareholders who took up their shares at £5 16s. According to the report, the first section had come by their own again, as had also those who paid £5 16s. for their shares. As he was the holder both those classes of shares, he was very grateful to the directors for what they had done for them.
The resolution was carried unanimously.
The Chairman proposed the re-election of Sir Walter Frederick Mieville, K.C.M.G., as a director of the company.
Mr. N. S. Stott seconded the motion, which was agreed to.
The Chairman next proposed the re-election of Mr. R.C. Johnston as a director, remarking that he had been connected with the company for nearly twenty-five years.
This was seconded by Viscount Hampden and agreed to.
On the motion of Mr. West, Messrs. Price, Waterhouse and Co. were reappointed auditors.

Replying to a question, Sir W.F. Mieville said he did not like Mr. Huri to take the entire responsibility of saying that they were fairly well assured of paying a dividend of 10 per cent. in the future; but, as Mr. Huri very properly put it, as far as human foresight and care went, they hoped to do so. He did not want Mr. Huri to take the whole onus of that, supposing it should turn out to be wrong ; but he wished to say that it was his (the speaker's) opinion---and he was in Egypt his year---that they would be able to do it easily for some time to come.

Mr. Huri then addressed the meeting, at the invitation of the shareholders. After thanking the chairman for the very flattering remarks he had made about himself, he stated that the report and the lucid remarks of the chairman had fully explained the position of the company, and therefore it was not necessary for him to address them at any length. Although the interest on loans had gradually diminished, they hoped to continue to invest their money, in very safe loans, at rates which would enable the board to continue to pay a dividend of 10 per cent. (Hear, hear.)
On the motion of Mr. Skeel, a vote of thanks was given to the chairman and directors, the speaker remarking that it was the first time that a ten percent. dividend had been paid.
The Chairman briefly acknowledged the compliment, and the proceedings terminated.

div.head: THE TRADE OF EGYPT
CUSTOMS RETURNS FOR APRIL
div.p: Egyptian trade continues to make very satisfactory progress. The totals of the imports month by month show considerable increases over those of last year, and the expansive power of the Egyptian imports appears to be limitless. Last year, the total value of the imports, exclusive of tobacco, was L.E. 19, 889,000, or L.E. 3,742,600 more than in 1903. It was difficult to believe that the imports would show much of a surplus over the figures month by month of the record year that has just passed. Yet as month by month passes of the present year, steady progress is maintained, and from the beginning of the year to the end of last month the value of the imports, L.E. 6,441,159, shows an increase of L.E. 640,342 over the figures for the corresponding period of last year, L.E. 5,801,119. The total for last month was L.E. 1,602,959, a surplus of L.E. 87,357 over April, 1904.

The imports from England in April amounted to L.E. 573,724, as against L.E. 521,879 for the same month last year. For the first four months the imports from home totalled L.E. 2,146,677, against L.E. 1,962,977 for the corresponding period in the previous year.

The biggest increase in imports last month was in cotton textures, which amounted to L.E. 248,658, or L.E. 43,388 over the previous April. This class of imports for the first four months of this year amounted in value to L.E. 971,703, an increase of L.E. 216,868 over the same period in 1904.

The exports for April amounted to L.E. 1,521,871, an increase of L.E. 70,869. Owing to the decrease in cotton exports since the beginning of the year. L.E. 1,968,075 less than the corresponding four months in 1904, there is a good deal of leeway to make up, and the total exports from January 1 to the 30th ulto. L.E. 7,025,998, show a decrease of L.E. 1,691,480 compared with the same period the previous year.

The exports to England in April amounted to L.E. 805,991, as against L.E. 698,788 in the previous April. The chief increase in the April exports was in sugar cane, L.E. 50,073, an increase of L.E. 45,597. Next came onions, L.E. 181,183, an increase of L.E. 33,262. Cotton seed was a bad third, L.E. 116,751, an increase of L.E. 15,902. The increases in these three classes of exports during the first four months of the year compared with the same period in 1904 have been made respectively, L.E. 201, 054, L.E. 83,222, and L.E. 7,850. The biggest decreases during the same period, exclusive of cotton, have been in the case of beans, eggs, and rice, which show decreases compared with the first four months of 1904 respectively of L.E. 22,588, L.E. 19,534, and L.E. 13,861.

div.head: HEIHACHIRO TOGO
div.p: Heihachiro Togo, the great naval commander, who has so signally distinguished himself, was born in 1857, and educated at the naval school, the Heigakuryo, where, among his boy contemporaries, were two youths, destined in later days to be known to the world as Admiral Ito and the present Naval Minister, Baron Yamamoto. Togo's father was Kichizaemon Togo, a member of the Samurai or warrior caste, and one of the class of which Ito and Field-Marshal Yamagata are also members. In his sixteenth year, young Togo was sent by the Emperor to England, to the Thames Nautical Training College, on board H.M.S. "Worcester," and it will surprise no one to learn that his conduct while there was officiailly stated to be "very good." Having returned to his native country, he in due course entered the Navy, and the great career with which all are now familiar began. For a long time he, of course, could only serve his Sovereign in time of peace, but during the year which preceded the war with China he was busy, watchful, faithful, ever on the look out for something that could be improved, winning the confidence of his superiors, the esteem of his equals, and the intense admiration of those who were under him ; and the result of it all was that when the war with China broke out, it found Captain Togo in command of the "Naniwa," one of the vessels in Rear-Admiral Tsuboi's fleet. With the luck which is said to be his, it fell to him to strike the first blow of the war, sinking the "Kowshing" with the swiftnesss with which he has sunk so many Russian vessels as of late. His promotion was swift, and as commander of the squadron that destroyed the Chinese fleet, he was raised to be Admiral; and when, a year ago, it began to be realised in Tokio that war with an infinitely greater power than China was inevitably, the finger of the whole country was at once pointed to Togo as the man to lead the Japanese fleet to victory and lure the Russian warships to destructions. He was duly appointed, and calmly and deliberately he laid down his plans. With what a deadly certainly they have been carried out the whole world knows to-day.

div.head: "WEARY OF ALL RELIGION."
div.p: Archdeacon Kilner, delivering last week the archidisconal charge at Skipton, said there could be no doubt that there was a general decline in the observance of the Lord's Day. Among causes tending to this result were, he said, the utter weariness in men's minds as to all religion, in consequence of the ceaseless public disputes which have coloured the last 50 years, on questions of faith and practice.

div.head: GREEKS AND JEWS AT BRAILA
div.p: A very large proportion of the trade of the Danube passes through Braila, which is one of the principal ports of Roumania, and which owes its importance to its geographical position and to the trade in corn. Formerly the greater part of the trade was in the hands of the Greeks, who are very numerous at Braila, but, according to the "Bulletin d'Orient," of late years a great number of Jews have settled in the town, and have seriously menaced the monopoly of the Greeks. As the greater part of the commerce of Braila depends on the grain trade, a poor harvest naturally a very bad effet on the port, and the more so as the Roumanian peasants live almost entirely on maize, and as the Government prohibits the export when the crop is short. The Greeks have the greatest number of vessels engaged in the trade, as they possessed last year one hundred and twenty-six ships, but Great Britain came next with ninety-one, and Austria, Holland, and France followed in the order named. But the effects of a bad year may be judged by the fact that in 1903 the Greeks had over two hundred steamers plying at the port, with a tonnage nearly double that of last year. The fact is that the shipping trade of the Danube is in a bad state, owing ot the competition of the shipowners and of the railways, which between them have lowered the freights to an unrenumerative rate.

div.head: RUSSIA AND AFGHANISTAN
div.p: Afghanistan, and, in fact, the outlook in Central Asia generally, are occupying public attention in Russia. Thus the "Bourse Gazette" discusses Afghanistan :–"Is it now the time for thinking about Central Asian affairs, when we have on our shoulders the burden of the war in the Far East---a war which has cost us already so many sacrifices and which is calling upon us now to make colossal efforts? How can Russia think about Afghanistan at this moment, when Russia itself must before all else extricate itself from its own internal complicated crisis, which has lasted all too long, which becomes more mischievous in character from day to day, and which demands all the spiritual and material strength at the disposal of Russia? We know that Russia's misfortune in war has aroused the appetites of its traditional foes, that it has given wings to their old hopes, and that it has inspired their speeches, the tone of which has shown us that, in their opinion, Russia is weakened, helpless, and isolated for some time to come. But we know well that their open and secret work will remain stillborn if only the Russian Empire comes out honorably from its honorable crisis. Towards that end, which is the only important end in view, all our efforts must be directed. Then everything else will come to us in the end."

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer, des Telegraphes et du Port d'Alexandrie
AVIS
div.p: Le Conseil d'Administration a l'honneur d'informer le public qu'il a besoin de 6 eleves qui seront exerces au Services des Magasins en vue d'etre designes en qualite d'aide magasiniers dans la Haute ou dans la Basse-Egypte. Un councours sera tenu le 15 Juin prochain au bureau de Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins a Saptieh (Quartier Boulac, Caire) pour l'engagement de ces eleves
Les candidats devront remplir les conditions suivantes :
1) Etre de nationalite Egyptienne.
2) Etre de bonne conduite.
3) Savoir lire et ecrire l'arabe ainsi que l'anglais. Au cas ou il se trouverait des candidats d'egal merite, la preference sera donnes a ceux qui sont munis du Certificat d'etudes primaires.
4) Etre physiquement aptes au service des Chemines de fer.
5) Etre ages de 18 a 25 ans au plus.

6) Signer, a leur admission, l'engagement de travailler soit dans la Haute soit dans la Basse-Egypte durant la totalite ou une partie de leur temps de service, suivant que l'Administration le leur ordonners.
7) Si pendant la periode d'apprentissage, ils ne donnent pas des preuves satisfaisantes, ils seront licencies, sans avoir le droit de reclamer quoi que ce soit.

8) Les candidats, qui prenneut part a ce concours, payeront leur prix de voyage au Caire. Toutefois il sera accorde a ceux d'entre eux qui seront recus un permis de voyage gratuit pour la localite ou ils auront a faire leur apprentissage.
Les candidats desirant prendre part au concours devront, avant le 5 Juin 1905, envoyer avec leurs noms les certificats ci-apres a Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins :
1) Un certificat de bonne conduite signe par le Mamour du Markaz dont ils relevent et par l'Omdeh de leur localite respective.
2) Les garanties habituelles.
Au recu de ces documents, leurs noms seront inscrits et une carte d'admission leur sera envoyee par Mr. le Chef du Service de Magasins.

Les candidats qui se presentoront au lieu du concours auront avant tout a subir un examen medical pour la constantation de leur aptitude physique et ne seront autorises a prendre part au concours que quand cette aptitude aura ete reconneu en eux.

Les 6 candidats qui seront reconnus les plus aptes par la Commission d'examen tant au point de vue de la conduite qu'a celui des qualites physqiues et intellectuelles seront engages en qualite d'apprentis aides-magasiniers pendant une periode d'essai de 6 mois. Si, durant cette periode, ils donnent des preuves tout-a-fait satisfaisantes, ils seront, a l'expiration des 6 mois, designes aides-magasiniers au salaire de L.E. 4 pour commencer.
Le Caire, le 26 mai 1905. 26037-1.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: Two vacancies exst in the Sudan Medical Department for two qualified Doctors of Egyptian or Syrian nationality (Mohammedan preferred).

After one year's satisfactory probation suitable candidates will be given the option of being placed on the permanent list and coming under the Government Pension scheme.
The probationary year will count towards service for Pension.
Candidates should be unmarried, healthy, and under 26 years of age.

The appointment is subject to the general Government Regulations in force at the time being as regards leave, travelling allowance and matters of discipline ; two months' leave is given every year as far as possible.

Testimonials (not more than three)---one, if possible, from an English official---may be sent to the Director Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum, not later than 31st May 1905 with a letter of application in the candidate's own handwriting, stating his qualification and his appointments since being qualified.

Tout porteur d'actions anciennes a du chef des actions par lui possedees un droit de preference a la souscription d'une action nouvelle pour cing actions anciennes sans attribution de fractions. Les actions non souscrities en vertu de ce droit de preference seront attribuees a la souscription publique.

Les porteurs d'actions anciennes qui voudront exercer leur droit de preference devront d'ici au 8 Juin 1905 inclusivement, a peine de decheance, faire leur souscription de ce chef aux endroits oi lessus designes avec depot des titres par eux possedes et versement du montant du premier terme de £2.10/ par action.

Les actions nou souscrites par les actionnaires en vertu de leur droit de preference sont offertes a la souscription publique. Les actionnaires qui independeamment des actions par eux souscrites en vertu de leur droit de preference, vondraient prendre part a la souscription publique, devront, de ce deruier chef, remplir la formule de souscription speciale a cet effet.
La souscription sera close, tant pour les actionnaires que pour le public, le 8 juin a midi et demi.
ELWIN PALMER.
Le Caire, le 26 mai 1905. 26025-12-4

div.head: NOTICE.
SUDAN GOVERNMENT.
CIVIL COURTS OF JUSTICE
div.p: The Sudan Government requires an interpreter for the Civil Courts of Justice, with a knowledge of Arabic, English, and Greek. He must read and write the three languages.
Applications to be addressed to the Agent General Sudan Government, W. O., Cairo, up to the 10th June 1905. 26024-6a-8

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains ff the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh. Through service for goods between all stations Of the Company and over 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department. For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig 21416 31-½2 905
